Tom Logan

Tom is a PhD student in the department of industrial and operations engineering at The University of Michigan - Ann Arbor. Originally from New Zealand, he completed his undergraduate studies at The University of Canterbury, Christchurch. The city, at that time, faced a series of earthquakes providing him first-hand experience of how cities respond to natural disasters. Tom's research interests include the design of sustainable and resilient cities, in order to make urban spaces more environmentally and societally friendly. He is currently exploring a range of modelling techniques, including network theory, data analytics, and system dynamics in which to use to apply to this subject.

Qualifications

Master of Science, Geography and Environmental Engineering 2015 The Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, USA
Bachelor of Science, Mathematics 2014 University of Canterbury, New Zealand
Bachelor of Engineering with Honours (1st Class), Natural Resources Engineering 2013 University of Canterbury, New Zealand
Thesis:"Optimisation for Heavy Metal Contaminant Treatment in Urban Catchments"

Awards

Fulbright New Zealand Science and Innovation Graduate Award
2014
Gordon Croft Fellowship
2014 Environment, Energy, Sustainability, and Health Institute (E²SHI)
Dean Robert H. Roy Fellowship
2014
J R Templin Postgraduate Scholarship
2013

Contacts

Projects and Publications

Prediction models

Tom M Logan, Stella McLeod

If we could predict the size of fruit before harvest, growers would be really happy. Models in past have had varying success; sometimes the studies don't check how good the model is for prediction. Using data mining I build a predictive model for apples and discuss how to check how good it is.

More info

Blog

Is the world warming?

There have been competing claims on the behaviour of the global temperature in recent years. Who says what, what do they say, and where does the evidence point?
